text.p: These are the headlines from selected Canadian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Authority to buy Terminal 3: Sale to GTAA fuels speculation Ottawa hoping to end Pearson suit before election.
- Margin investors stung by Bre-X: Many thousands lost many millions.
- Teachers offered early retirement: Ontario proposal would allow some to leave without taking hit in their pension.
- Protest dogs grizzly hunt: Loss of habitat called a danger.
- Probes put care agencies on trial: Battered Ontario baby was CAS ward.
- Union reforms stay, Labour leader says: Party won't rescind Thatcher changes, Blair reassures British voters in letter.
- Wily Mobutu may buy off his rebel foes: Analysts expect Zairian leader will accept the fact he can't win the battle, and do the next best thing: bribe Kabila.
- Bre-X trading halted again: TSE awaits Busang information; firm faces billion-dollar lawsuits.
- Bears bite Toronto, U.S. stock markets: Interest rate, earnings fears spur sell-off.
- Scotiabank pushing deeper in South America: Spending C$200 million on expansion.
- Bank, gold shares feel brunt of market anxiety.
- Bre-X set to battle it out: Beleaguered gold miner defends analysis of Busang ore samples and threatens to sue its critics - but U.S. lawsuits have already begun to accuse the company of fraud.
